p:
We confirmed that all swab samples from the deceased infant chimpanzee were positive for rhinovirus C by Luminex assay. Two of the 41 fecal samples collected during the epidemic were positive for enteroviruses, but subsequent molecular typing using published methods (
28 ) demonstrated these to be nonrhinovirus enteroviruses, which occur in wild apes without known clinical significance (
14 ,
29 ,
30 ). Fifteen samples were also positive for adenoviruses by Luminex assay. Subsequent typing of these viruses by PCR and direct sequencing of a portion of the hexon gene according to published methods (
31 ) was successful for 11 samples. The resulting sequences (GenBank accession nos. KY624838‒KY624848) were identical or closely related to adenoviruses found in fecal samples from apparently healthy wild chimpanzees and other nonhuman primates (
32 –
35 ) ( Technical Appendix Figure 2).
